title: Politics › Opposition to demand extra Diet session to question new ministers
text:
( 0 ) TOKYO — 
Five Japanese opposition parties decided Monday to submit a demand for the government and ruling parties to convene an extraordinary Diet session soon to allow for the questioning of new cabinet ministers, opposition lawmakers said. 
The demand will be made at a meeting Tuesday of the secretaries general of the opposition parties, including the Democratic Party of Japan, and the ruling coalition of the Liberal Democratic Party and Komeito party, the lawmakers said. 
The government and ruling camp are considering not convening an extra session due to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s tight diplomatic schedule, but the opposition lawmakers said the government is seeking to avoid parliamentary debate on a money scandal involving one of the ministers appointed in a Cabinet reshuffle in early October. 
New farm minister Hiroshi Moriyama has confirmed media reports that the LDP chapter he heads received 6.9 million yen over three years from some companies that the Kagoshima prefectural government barred in 2010 from bidding for public works contracts due to bid rigging. 
In October last year, new female cabinet ministers Yuko Obuchi and Midori Matsushima resigned over money and election scandals after being grilled during an extra Diet session convened in late September. 
The DPJ, the Japan Innovation Party, the Japanese Communist Party, the Social Democratic Party and the People’s Life Party will question new Cabinet ministers on their policies if the extra Diet session is convened. 
If the ruling bloc refuses to hold a session, the opposition parties will invoke Article 53 of the Constitution requiring the government to convene an extraordinary Diet session if requested by at least a quarter of lawmakers in the lower or upper house, a senior DPJ lawmaker said. 
The constitutional provision, however, lacks a deadline for the convening of such a session, effectively leaving it to the government to decide when to hold it. 
Extra parliamentary sessions have been held in the fall almost every year. 
The opposition parties also plan to use the proposed session to grill the government over controversial national security legislation enacted last month and a recent free trade accord involving Japan, the United States and 10 other Pacific Rim countries. 
Farmers, who are one of the major support bases of the LDP, have strong concerns over the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal. 
The government will make a final decision on an extra Diet session while coordinating with the ruling parties, Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga said Monday. © KYODO
